senses.sense: A Scandinavian knotted-pile woollen rug, used as bed-cover and tapestry.
Alternative form of rial (old English coin)
plural of rya
(architecture) A vertical dressed stone beside a door or window.
(obsolete) A gold coin of Zealand (Netherlands) worth 14 florins.
(obsolete) Alternative spelling of rider ("clause added to a document")
A grain used extensively in Europe for making bread, beer, and (now generally) for animal fodder.
The grass Secale cereale from which the grain is obtained.
Rye bread.
(US, Canada) Rye whiskey.
(US, Canada) A drink of rye.
Caraway (from the mistaken assumption that the whole seeds, often used to season rye bread, are the rye itself)
Ryegrass, any of the species of Lolium.
A disease of hawks.
(countable) Any of several species of tufted grasses of the genus Lolium.
examples: Perennial ryegrass is an important species for lawn seed mixes.

senses.sense: (uncountable) A collection of plants of any of the species, as in a lawn or field.
examples: We seeded the meadow with ryegrass to provide better forage.

senses.sense: plural of ryegrass
Alternative form of rypeck
plural of rye
A piece of iron crossing the hole in the upper millstone, by which the stone is supported on the spindle.
plural of rynd
(archaic, reflexive) stand off; move away (said by milkmaids to their cows after milking them)
A traditional Japanese inn with communal baths and other public areas.
(India) A farmer or tiller of the soil.
plural of ryot
Alternative form of ryotwari

(historical) In British India, a system used to collect revenues directly from the ryots (cultivators of agricultural land), as opposed to zamindari, where revenues were collected indirectly through zamindars.
A bird, the ptarmigan.
Obsolete spelling of ripe
(UK, dialect) A pole used to move a punt while fishing.
steller; a kind of sea cow
